M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, every lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, ensuring that tenants can enjoy their property free from interference by the landlord or others acting under the landlord's control.

M.G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this case arises under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses and applies the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, describing it as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy and the use of the premises. The court holds that if drug activity in the common areas renders them unusable, that constitutes a serious interference with quiet enjoyment, and focuses on whether this interference is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions. This aligns directly with the proposition that Doe interprets the covenant as protecting tenants from serious interference with their use and enjoyment of leased property.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Simon v. Soloman, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.raw_text: Simon v. Soloman, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (landlord’s failure to make repairs constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Soloman, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.proposition: Simon v. Soloman, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (landlord’s failure to make repairs constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Soloman, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.support_reasoning: The opinion directly treats interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, and applies it to the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions—i.e., to make needed repairs. The court holds that Gem’s omission to fix the porous wall and prevent repeated flooding both breached its duty to maintain habitable, sanitary conditions and constituted interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. That squarely supports using Simon v. Solomon as authority that a landlord’s failure to make necessary repairs can amount to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Soloman, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).raw_text: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (landlords are strictly liable under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 for violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (landlords are strictly liable under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 for violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects strict liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that at least negligent conduct is required for a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court contrasts this fault-based standard with the strict liability regime of the lead paint statute and clarifies that a statutory violation alone is insufficient to establish a § 14 breach. Therefore the case is contrary authority to the proposition that landlords are strictly liable under § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).proposition: Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977) (landlord must maintain premises in habitable condition and ensure tenants’ quiet enjoyment).
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common passageways under his control for lawful visitors, and that violation of a safety statute can be evidence of negligence. However, it does not use or adopt the specific concepts of an implied warranty of habitability or a broad duty to ensure tenants’ ‘quiet enjoyment’ of leased premises. Its focus is premises liability and statutory negligence toward visitors, not a general landlord obligation to maintain habitable conditions and quiet enjoyment for tenants as such.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).relevant_excerpt: “In summary, we hold that Massios owed Lindsey a duty to use reasonable care in the maintenance of the premises on which Lindsey was injured. If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider.”

Norfolk County, 262 Mass. 594 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the authority of a warehouseman’s officer to issue warehouse receipts and the resulting liability of a surety on a warehouseman’s bond. It does not involve a landlord–tenant relationship, nor does it discuss or apply any implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in a lease. Therefore, citing this case for a proposition about a landlord renting premises with an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is inaccurate and unsupported by the decision.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (landlord must maintain premises in livable condition).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (landlord must maintain premises in livable condition).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This is a concurring/dissenting opinion, but it explicitly agrees that the old rule of no landlord duty to maintain habitability should be rejected and that landlords renting dwelling units have an implied obligation tied to legal minimum standards of habitability. Although the concurrence would ground the duty specifically in compliance with the State Sanitary Code rather than a broader, undefined warranty, it still clearly endorses the core idea that a landlord must maintain premises in a livable (habitable) condition for tenants. Because this is not the majority opinion and the excerpt does not include the majority’s own formulation, confidence is medium rather than high.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’ … I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets and applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory quiet enjoyment provision), but it does not discuss the nature or purpose of the statute’s remedies as being punitive versus protective. The court’s analysis focuses on the standard of landlord fault (negligence suffices), when liability arises, and the availability of attorney’s fees; it does not characterize the statutory remedies’ function or purpose in the way the proposition describes. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition about the remedial nature of § 14 damages.
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”
… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown. On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.
